body:
## Code Review

This is an impressive and significant modernization of the Android project. The upgrades to Gradle, AGP, Kotlin, and Java, along with the migration from Dagger 1 to Dagger 2, are substantial and well-executed. The addition of CI/CD workflows and detailed documentation is also a great improvement.

I've found two critical issues in the refactored `RecyclerView` adapters that would lead to runtime crashes. I've provided suggestions to fix them. Additionally, I've included a couple of medium-severity recommendations to further improve encapsulation and continue the modernization of the reactive programming library used in the project.

Overall, this is a fantastic step forward for the project's health and maintainability. Great work!

**Actionable comments posted: 10**
♻️ Duplicate comments (3)
app/src/main/java/io/github/hidroh/materialistic/widget/SubmissionRecyclerViewAdapter.java (1)
`40-44`: **Critical issue from previous review remains unaddressed.** The previous review correctly identified that removing `onAttachedToRecyclerView` and relying on manual `attach` calls will cause crashes. Without the automatic lifecycle callback, any caller that forgets to invoke `attach` will encounter a `NullPointerException` at line 48 when `mLayoutInflater` is accessed (since it won't be initialized). You must restore `onAttachedToRecyclerView` to ensure automatic initialization: ```java @Override public void onAttachedToRecyclerView(@NonNull RecyclerView recyclerView) { super.onAttachedToRecyclerView(recyclerView); attach(recyclerView.getContext(), recyclerView); } @Override public void attach(Context context, RecyclerView recyclerView) { super.attach(context, recyclerView); ((MaterialisticApplication) context.getApplicationContext()).applicationComponent.inject(this); } ```
app/src/main/java/io/github/hidroh/materialistic/data/AlgoliaClient.java (1)
`52-52`: **Make `mHackerNewsClient` private and final.** The field should be `private final` to ensure proper encapsulation and immutability, as it's initialized via constructor injection and never modified.
🔎 Proposed fix ```diff - ItemManager mHackerNewsClient; // No @Inject here + private final ItemManager mHackerNewsClient; ```
app/src/main/java/io/github/hidroh/materialistic/widget/ThreadPreviewRecyclerViewAdapter.java (1)
`48-52`: **Critical: `attach()` method will never be called, causing NullPointerException.** The custom `attach()` method containing dependency injection logic is not invoked automatically. Without an `onAttachedToRecyclerView()` override to call `attach()`, the injected fields will remain null, resulting in a runtime crash when the adapter is used.
🔎 Recommended fix: Add onAttachedToRecyclerView override ```diff + @Override + public void onAttachedToRecyclerView(@NonNull RecyclerView recyclerView) { + super.onAttachedToRecyclerView(recyclerView); + attach(recyclerView.getContext(), recyclerView); + } + @Override public void attach(Context context, RecyclerView recyclerView) { super.attach(context, recyclerView); ((MaterialisticApplication) context.getApplicationContext()).applicationComponent.inject(this); mLevelIndicatorWidth = AppUtils.getDimensionInDp(mContext, R.dimen.level_indicator_width); } ```
Based on past review comments, this issue was previously identified and needs to be addressed.
🧹 Nitpick comments (9)
app/src/main/java/io/github/hidroh/materialistic/data/AlgoliaClient.java (2)
`53-53`: **Consider using constructor injection for all dependencies.** The class currently mixes constructor injection (`mHackerNewsClient`) with field injection (`mMainThreadScheduler`). For consistency with `HackerNewsClient` and `SessionManager` (see relevant code snippets), consider moving all dependencies to constructor injection.
🔎 Proposed refactor ```diff - @Inject @Named(DataModule.MAIN_THREAD) Scheduler mMainThreadScheduler; + private final Scheduler mMainThreadScheduler; @Inject - public AlgoliaClient(RestServiceFactory factory, @Named(HN) ItemManager hackerNewsClient) { + public AlgoliaClient(RestServiceFactory factory, + @Named(HN) ItemManager hackerNewsClient, + @Named(DataModule.MAIN_THREAD) Scheduler mainThreadScheduler) { mRestService = factory.rxEnabled(true).create(BASE_API_URL, RestService.class); mHackerNewsClient = hackerNewsClient; + mMainThreadScheduler = mainThreadScheduler; } ```
Also applies to: 56-59 --- `52-52`: **Remove redundant comment.** The comment `// No @Inject here` is self-evident from the code. Removing it improves clarity.
AGENTS.md (1)
`50-70`: **Consider documenting root cause of permission issues.** The troubleshooting section correctly addresses permission issues that may occur during builds. However, requiring `sudo` for build operations typically indicates underlying environment or containerization issues rather than being a normal part of the build process. Consider adding a note about investigating why ownership issues occur in the first place (e.g., container user mapping, volume mount permissions) rather than treating `sudo` as a routine workaround.
.github/workflows/release.yml (1)
`34-40`: **Consider adding APK signing for production releases.** The workflow builds and uploads an unsigned APK (`app-release-unsigned.apk`). For production releases, you'll need to sign the APK. Consider adding signing configuration using GitHub Secrets to store the keystore and credentials securely.
💡 Example signing configuration Add a signing step before the upload: ```yaml - name: Sign APK uses: r0adkll/sign-android-release@v1 with: releaseDirectory: app/build/outputs/apk/release signingKeyBase64: ${{ secrets.SIGNING_KEY }} alias: ${{ secrets.ALIAS }} keyStorePassword: ${{ secrets.KEY_STORE_PASSWORD }} keyPassword: ${{ secrets.KEY_PASSWORD }} ``` Then update the upload path: ```diff - name: Upload release APK uses: actions/upload-artifact@v4 with: name: app-release - path: app/build/outputs/apk/release/app-release-unsigned.apk + path: app/build/outputs/apk/release/app-release-signed.apk ```
app/build.gradle (1)
`87-91`: **Minor inconsistency in `kaptTest` declarations.** `kaptTest` is declared for `room-compiler` and `dagger-compiler` but not for `lifecycle-compiler`. If lifecycle annotations are used in tests, this could cause compilation issues. Consider adding `kaptTest "androidx.lifecycle:lifecycle-compiler:$lifecycleVersion"` for consistency, or remove it if intentionally omitted.
🔎 Suggested fix for consistency ```diff kapt "androidx.lifecycle:lifecycle-compiler:$lifecycleVersion" kapt "androidx.room:room-compiler:$roomVersion" kapt "com.google.dagger:dagger-compiler:$daggerVersion" +kaptTest "androidx.lifecycle:lifecycle-compiler:$lifecycleVersion" kaptTest "androidx.room:room-compiler:$roomVersion" kaptTest "com.google.dagger:dagger-compiler:$daggerVersion" ```
app/src/main/java/io/github/hidroh/materialistic/SubmitActivity.java (1)
`235-243`: **Inconsistent lifecycle checking between `isFinishing()` and `isDestroyed()`.** The PR description mentions replacing `isFinishing()` calls with `isDestroyed()`, but this was only partially applied: - Lines 306, 313: Use `isDestroyed()` in async callbacks ✓ - Lines 235, 242, 287: Still use `isFinishing()` For async callbacks, `isDestroyed()` is more robust as it checks if the activity is truly destroyed, not just finishing. Consider applying this consistently to lines 235, 242, and 287 as well, especially line 287 in `toggleControls()` which updates UI state.
🔎 Proposed fix for consistent lifecycle checking ```diff void onSubmitted(Boolean successful) { if (successful == null) { toggleControls(false); Toast.makeText(this, R.string.submit_failed, Toast.LENGTH_SHORT).show(); } else if (successful) { Toast.makeText(this, R.string.submit_successful, Toast.LENGTH_SHORT).show(); - if (!isFinishing()) { + if (!isDestroyed()) { Intent intent = new Intent(this, NewActivity.class); intent.putExtra(NewActivity.EXTRA_REFRESH, true); intent.setFlags(Intent.FLAG_ACTIVITY_REORDER_TO_FRONT); startActivity(intent); // TODO should go to profile instead? finish(); } - } else if (!isFinishing()) { + } else if (!isDestroyed()) { AppUtils.showLogin(this, mAlertDialogBuilder); } } ``` ```diff private void toggleControls(boolean sending) { - if (isFinishing()) { + if (isDestroyed()) { return; } mSending = sending; mTitleEditText.setEnabled(!sending); mContentEditText.setEnabled(!sending); supportInvalidateOptionsMenu(); } ```
Also applies to: 287-294, 306-309, 313-321
Changelog.md (1)
`27-27`: **Optional: Consider hyphenating compound adjective.** The phrase "Dagger 1 related" could be hyphenated as "Dagger 1-related" per standard grammar conventions for compound adjectives.
🔎 Proposed fix ```diff -- Removed all Dagger 1 related classes and interfaces, including `InjectableActivity` and `Injectable`. +- Removed all Dagger 1-related classes and interfaces, including `InjectableActivity` and `Injectable`. ```
app/src/main/java/io/github/hidroh/materialistic/MaterialisticApplication.java (1)
`6-7`: **Minor: License text formatting appears unintentional.** The line break after "You may" (lines 6-7) seems like an unintended reformatting compared to the standard Apache License 2.0 header format.
🔎 Proposed fix ```diff - * You may - * obtain a copy of the License at + * You may obtain a copy of the License at ```
app/src/main/java/io/github/hidroh/materialistic/UserActivity.java (1)
`61-61`: **Optional: Fix pre-existing typo in field name.** The field name `mItemManger` appears to have a typo (missing 'a'). Consider renaming to `mItemManager` for consistency and clarity. Note this is a pre-existing issue, not introduced by this PR.

🔇 Additional comments (64)
app/src/main/java/io/github/hidroh/materialistic/preference/FontPreference.java (2)
`27-27`: **LGTM! Application → MaterialisticApplication migration is correct.** The import and field reference updates correctly align with the migration from the legacy `Application` class to `MaterialisticApplication` as part of the Dagger 2 refactoring. Also applies to: 59-59 --- `46-46`: **Verify dropdown layout renders correctly with font previews.** The layout resource changed from a custom support layout (`R.layout.support_simple_spinner_dropdown_item`) to the standard Android system layout (`android.R.layout.simple_spinner_dropdown_item`). This change appears unrelated to the Dagger migration and could affect the dropdown appearance. Please verify that: - The font dropdown still displays correctly - Font previews are visible in the dropdown items (line 52 sets custom typeface)
app/src/main/java/io/github/hidroh/materialistic/appwidget/WidgetService.java (3)
`37-38`: **LGTM—clean migration to static imports.** The static imports for DI qualifiers simplify the @Named annotations and align with the Dagger 2 migration pattern. --- `54-57`: **ApplicationComponent declares inject(WidgetService) method correctly.** The Dagger 2 component injection pattern is correctly implemented. ApplicationComponent has the required `void inject(WidgetService widgetService)` method declaration. --- `50-51`: **Injection qualifiers are properly matched.** The @Named(HN) and @Named(ALGOLIA) qualifiers used in WidgetService correctly reference the statically imported constants from DataModule, where the corresponding @Provides methods provide ItemManager instances with matching @Named qualifiers. The dependency injection will resolve correctly.
app/src/main/java/io/github/hidroh/materialistic/preference/SimpleSpinnerPreference.java (1)
`44-44`: **Same theming concern as FontSizePreference.** This change mirrors the layout switch in `FontSizePreference.java`. The same theming and visual consistency concerns apply here—using the built-in Android framework layout instead of the AppCompat version may affect appearance across themes and API levels. ## Code Review

This is a significant and well-executed pull request that modernizes the project's build system and dependency injection framework. The upgrade to Java 21, along with the latest Gradle and AGP versions, is a crucial step forward. The migration from Dagger 1 to Dagger 2 has been handled thoroughly across the codebase. The addition of documentation for CI/CD, development environment setup, and outstanding issues is also highly commendable.

My review comments focus on potential areas for further improvement, such as migrating away from legacy libraries like RxJava 1, refining dependency injection patterns for better testability, and improving the clarity of documentation and code comments. Overall, this is excellent progress on a complex set of changes.

## Code Review

This pull request represents a significant modernization of the project, including upgrading the build system to support Java 21, migrating from Dagger 1 to Dagger 2, and setting up CI/CD with GitHub Actions. The changes are extensive and well-executed, moving the project towards more modern Android development practices.

My review focuses on a few areas for improvement:
- There are some inconsistencies in version numbers across the new documentation files (`AGENTS.md`, `Changelog.md`) and the build configuration. Aligning these will improve clarity.
- The method for embedding the git hash into the version name in `app/build.gradle` could be made more robust and platform-independent.

Overall, this is a fantastic effort to update the project's foundations. The migration to Dagger 2 and the build system upgrades are particularly noteworthy improvements.

![medium](https://www.gstatic.com/codereviewagent/medium-priority.svg)

This pull request does a great job modernizing the project. As a next step, consider migrating from RxJava 1 (`io.reactivex:rxjava:1.3.8`) to a more recent version like RxJava 3 or to Kotlin Coroutines. RxJava 1 is no longer maintained and lacks many of the features and performance improvements of later versions. This would be a significant step towards fully modernizing the codebase.

![medium](https://www.gstatic.com/codereviewagent/medium-priority.svg)

It's great that you've switched to constructor injection. To further improve encapsulation, you should make `mHackerNewsClient` a `private final` field, as it's initialized in the constructor and should not be modified from outside the class.

```suggestion
    private final ItemManager mHackerNewsClient;
```

body:
_⚠️ Potential issue_ | _🟠 Major_

<details>
<summary>🧩 Analysis chain</summary>

🌐 Web query:

`Gradle 8.6 compatibility Android Gradle Plugin 8.4.0`

💡 Result:

Yes — Android Gradle Plugin (AGP) 8.4.0 requires Gradle 8.6 (minimum and default). Use Gradle 8.6 with AGP 8.4.0. [1][2]

Sources:
- AGP 8.4.0 release notes (compatibility table). [1]
- AGP ↔ Gradle compatibility table. [2]

---

🌐 Web query:

`latest stable Gradle version 2025 2026`

💡 Result:

The latest stable Gradle release (as of Jan 3, 2026) is Gradle 9.2.1 — released on November 17, 2025. [1][2]

Sources:
- Gradle install page (current release: 9.2.1). [1]
- Gradle 9.2.0/9.2.x release notes. [2]

---

🌐 Web query:

`Gradle 8.6 breaking changes known issues Java 21 Kotlin`

💡 Result:

Short summary of known/breaking issues when upgrading to Gradle 8.6 (Java 21 / Kotlin):

- Gradle 8.6 release notes and known-issues: read upgrade instructions and known issues before upgrading. [1]

- Java 21: Gradle (8.5+) supports compiling for Java 21, but builds that mix Gradle/JVM runtime, Kotlin compiler and Java 21 can show problems unless you use Java toolchains or compatible Kotlin versions. If you see "Inconsistent JVM-target compatibility" (compileJava vs compileKotlin) or runtime errors, configure Gradle Java toolchains and align Kotlin's jvmTarget. [2][3]

- Kotlin / multiplatform interactions:
  - Gradle >8.6 introduces deprecation warnings around using withJava() in Kotlin Multiplatform projects; this will become an error in Gradle 9.0. Check Kotlin plugin compatibility and upgrade Kotlin if needed. [4]
  - The Kotlin Gradle plugin relies on toolchains for consistent jvmTarget behavior; set the toolchain and/or explicitly set kotlin.jvm.target/compilerOptions.jvmTarget to the same Java major version as your Java toolchain. Also consider kotlin.jvm.target.validation.mode if you need to relax checks. [2][4]

Common fixes and recommendations
- Use Gradle Java toolchains so Kotlin and Java compilation targets match (configure both Java and Kotlin toolchains). [2][4]
- Explicitly set Kotlin jvmTarget/compilerOptions.jvmTarget to the Java major version you intend (e.g., 21) to avoid "inconsistent JVM-target" errors. [2]
- Upgrade the Kotlin Gradle plugin to a version that documents compatibility with Gradle 8.6 / Java 21 (check Kotlin release notes for the exact minimum). [4]
- If problems persist, consult the Gradle 8.6 release notes known-issues and file/report issues on Gradle/Kotlin trackers. [1][3]

Sources
[1] Gradle 8.6 release notes / known issues.  
[2] Kotlin docs — Gradle configuration, toolchains and JVM-target validation.  
[3] Gradle GitHub issues discussing Java 21 / Kotlin runtime compatibility.  
[4] Kotlin Multiplatform compatibility guide (notes about withJava() deprecation and Gradle >8.6).

---



</details>

**Configure Gradle Java toolchain and Kotlin jvmTarget to resolve Java 21 compatibility.**

Gradle 8.6 is required by Android Gradle Plugin 8.4.0, so the version choice is correct. However, Java 21 + Kotlin 2.2.20 builds require explicit configuration: ensure Gradle Java toolchains are enabled and Kotlin's jvmTarget matches the Java compilation target. Mismatched JVM targets between Java and Kotlin compilation can cause "Inconsistent JVM-target compatibility" errors and may contribute to the current R class generation issue. Configure both Gradle and Kotlin toolchains to use Java 21 consistently.

<summary>🤖 Prompt for AI Agents</summary>

```
In gradle/wrapper/gradle-wrapper.properties around line 3, ensure Gradle 8.6
will drive Java 21 by configuring the project and Kotlin toolchains: in the root

JavaLanguageVersion.of(21) (or 21), and in each module build.gradle(.kts) set

Java 21). Also make sure the Android Gradle Plugin compileOptions and
kotlinOptions (or kotlin jvm toolchain) use Java 21 so Java and Kotlin
compilation targets match consistently across the project.
```

@@ -0,0 +1,75 @@
+# AGENTS.md
+
+This document provides instructions for agents and automated systems to work with this repository.
+
+## Development Environment Setup
+
+The project has been upgraded to a modern Android build environment. Strict adherence to these versions is required to ensure a successful build.
+
+### 1. Java Development Kit (JDK)
+
+- **Version:** Java 21 is mandatory.
+- **Installation:**
+  ```bash
+  sudo apt-get update && sudo apt-get install -y openjdk-21-jdk
+  ```
+- **Verification:** Ensure Java 21 is the default version:
+  ```bash
+  java -version
+  ```
+
+### 2. Android SDK
+
+- **`compileSdk`:** 33
+- **`targetSdk`:** 33
+- **`minSdk`:** 21
+- **`buildToolsVersion`:** The Android Gradle Plugin will automatically download the required version. Ensure the `ANDROID_HOME` environment variable is correctly set to your SDK location.
+
+### 3. Gradle
+
+- **Gradle Version:** 8.6
+- **Android Gradle Plugin (AGP) Version:** 8.4.0
+- **Kotlin Version:** 2.2.20
+- The Gradle wrapper (`./gradlew`) is included in the repository and should be used for all build commands. It will automatically download the correct Gradle version.
+
+## Building the Project
+
+- **Clean the project:**
+  ```bash
+  ./gradlew clean
+  ```
+- **Build a debug APK:**
+  ```bash
+  ./gradlew assembleDebug
+  ```
+- **Run unit tests:**
+  ```bash
+  ./gradlew test
+  ```
+
+## Troubleshooting
+
+### Build Failures due to `Permission denied`
+
+During the build process, you may encounter `Permission denied` errors related to the `.gradle` or `.kotlin` directories in the project root. This is often due to file ownership issues within the sandbox environment.
+
+**Solution:**
+
+Before running a build, ensure the current user owns these directories by running the following commands from the repository root:
+
+```bash
+sudo chown -R $(whoami) .gradle/
+sudo chown -R $(whoami) .kotlin/
+```
+
+If the build fails with an error related to deleting the `app/build` directory, you may need to remove it manually with `sudo`:
+
+```bash
+sudo rm -rf app/build
+```
body:
![medium](https://www.gstatic.com/codereviewagent/medium-priority.svg)

The troubleshooting steps are very helpful. However, the repeated use of `sudo` for `chown` and `rm` might indicate an underlying permission issue in the development or CI environment, potentially from running Gradle or other tools as root previously. While this is a valid fix, it could be beneficial to add a note about avoiding running tools with `sudo` in the first place to prevent these permission problems. For CI environments, configuring the runner to use the correct user permissions would be a more robust solution.

body:
![medium](https://www.gstatic.com/codereviewagent/medium-priority.svg)

This pull request does a great job of modernizing the build environment. As a next step for modernization, consider migrating from RxJava 1 to a more recent reactive streams solution. RxJava 1 is quite old and no longer maintained. Migrating to RxJava 3 or Kotlin Coroutines would bring benefits in terms of performance, features, and community support.

![medium](https://www.gstatic.com/codereviewagent/medium-priority.svg)

This comment seems to be a note for the reviewer and can be removed. The change to constructor injection is a great improvement!

```suggestion
    ItemManager mHackerNewsClient;
```

![medium](https://www.gstatic.com/codereviewagent/medium-priority.svg)

While this approach to dependency injection works and is consistent with the previous Dagger 1 implementation, it's generally better to use constructor injection for adapters. This improves testability and makes dependencies explicit. Consider refactoring this to pass dependencies through the constructor. The `ItemFragment` (or other class creating this adapter) could be responsible for providing these dependencies.

![medium](https://www.gstatic.com/codereviewagent/medium-priority.svg)

Executing `git` commands directly within the Gradle build script can lead to issues. The build will fail on machines where `git` is not installed or not in the system's PATH. It also introduces a performance overhead as it runs on every configuration.

Consider using a Gradle plugin like `com.gorylenko.gradle-git-properties` to fetch git information in a more robust and platform-independent way.

## Summary of Changes Hello @sheepdestroyer, I'm Gemini Code Assist[^1]! I'm currently reviewing this pull request and will post my feedback shortly. In the meantime, here's a summary to help you and other reviewers quickly get up to speed! This pull request represents a substantial effort to modernize the Android project's underlying build infrastructure and introduce a robust CI/CD pipeline. The changes aim to improve maintainability and automate development workflows by upgrading core dependencies like Gradle, AGP, Kotlin, and Java, and by migrating the dependency injection framework from Dagger 1 to Dagger 2. While the CI/CD workflows are now defined and documented, the project is currently in a work-in-progress state, with a known build blocker related to Android Resource class generation that requires further investigation. ### Highlights * **Build System Modernization**: The project's build environment has been significantly updated, including upgrades to Gradle (8.6), Android Gradle Plugin (8.4.0), Kotlin (2.2.20), and Java (21). * **Dagger Migration**: The dependency injection framework has been migrated from Dagger 1 to Dagger 2, involving extensive refactoring of application and activity modules, and injection points across the codebase. * **CI/CD Pipeline Introduction**: New GitHub Actions workflows have been added for Continuous Integration (CI) on pull requests and automated Release builds on new tag pushes, establishing a foundational CI/CD process. * **New Documentation**: Several new Markdown files (`AGENTS.md`, `CI.md`, `Changelog.md`, `TODO.md`) have been added to document the new build setup, CI/CD processes, and track remaining issues. * **Current Build Blocker**: The project currently faces a critical build issue where the Android Resource (R) class is not being generated, leading to numerous compilation failures, as detailed in the new `TODO.md`.

📝 Walkthrough ## Walkthrough This pull request performs a major migration from Dagger 1 to Dagger 2 for dependency injection, upgrades build tooling (Java 21, Gradle 8.6, Android Gradle Plugin 8.4.0, Kotlin 2.2.20), adds GitHub Actions CI/CD workflows, renames the Application class to MaterialisticApplication, and refactors Activities to extend ThemedActivity instead of InjectableActivity. Documentation and configuration files support these architectural and infrastructure changes. ## Changes | Cohort / File(s) | Summary | |---|---| | **CI/CD Workflows**
`.github/workflows/ci.yml`, `.github/workflows/release.yml` | Added GitHub Actions workflows for automated testing on PRs to main (CI) and release builds on tag pushes (Release). Both configured with JDK 21, Android SDK API 33, Gradle caching, and appropriate build/test steps. | | **Documentation**
`AGENTS.md`, `CI.md`, `Changelog.md`, `README.md`, `TODO.md` | Added comprehensive documentation: agent/build setup instructions, CI/CD workflow descriptions, changelog with migration details, updated Java version requirement to JDK 21, and build blocker tracking. | | **Build Configuration**
`build.gradle`, `gradle.properties`, `gradle/wrapper/gradle-wrapper.properties`, `app/build.gradle` | Upgraded Gradle wrapper to 8.6, Android Gradle Plugin to 8.4.0, Kotlin to 2.2.20; enabled buildConfig; updated Java 11 to Java 21; migrated Dagger 1.2.5 to 2.51.1; updated okHttp and AndroidX dependencies; reorganized dependency declarations with explicit kapt entries. | | **Dependency Injection Framework**
`app/src/main/java/io/github/hidroh/materialistic/ApplicationModule.java`, `ApplicationComponent.java`, `ActivityModule.java`, `DataModule.java`, `NetworkModule.java`, `UiModule.java`, `InjectableActivity.java` | Migrated from Dagger 1 ObjectGraph approach to Dagger 2 component-based DI. Introduced ApplicationComponent singleton with ApplicationModule providing Context. Moved string constants (HN, ALGOLIA, POPULAR) from ActivityModule to DataModule. Simplified module annotations removing library/complete flags. **Removed** InjectableActivity which previously managed activity-level graph composition. | | **Application Entry Point & Manifest**
`app/src/main/java/io/github/hidroh/materialistic/MaterialisticApplication.java`, `app/src/main/AndroidManifest.xml` | Renamed Application to MaterialisticApplication; removed Injectable implementation; introduced public ApplicationComponent field initialized in onCreate. Updated manifest to reference MaterialisticApplication. | | **Activities – Base Classes**
`app/src/main/java/io/github/hidroh/materialistic/AboutActivity.kt`, `AccountAuthenticatorActivity.java`, `ComposeActivity.java`, `DrawerActivity.java`, `FeedbackActivity.java`, `ItemActivity.java`, `OfflineWebActivity.java`, `ReleaseNotesActivity.kt`, `SettingsActivity.java`, `SubmitActivity.java`, `ThreadPreviewActivity.java`, `UserActivity.java`, `appwidget/WidgetConfigActivity.java` | Changed all Activities from extending InjectableActivity to ThemedActivity. Added explicit dependency injection calls via `applicationComponent.inject(this)` in onCreate. Updated ItemManager injection qualifiers from `@Named(ActivityModule.HN)` to `@Named(HN)`. Updated lifecycle checks from isActivityDestroyed() to isDestroyed() in callbacks. | | **Fragments**
`app/src/main/java/io/github/hidroh/materialistic/ItemFragment.java`, `ListFragment.java`, `WebFragment.java`, `BaseFragment.java` | Added DI invocation in onAttach/onActivityCreated for fragments. Updated ItemManager qualifiers to use static imports from DataModule. Removed injection from BaseFragment onActivityCreated. | | **Services & Background Jobs**
`app/src/main/java/io/github/hidroh/materialistic/data/ItemSyncService.java`, `ItemSyncJobService.java`, `appwidget/WidgetService.java` | Replaced Injectable/ActivityModule injection pattern with direct applicationComponent.inject(this) calls. Updated ItemManager qualifiers from ActivityModule constants to DataModule static imports. | | **Adapters & Widgets**
`app/src/main/java/io/github/hidroh/materialistic/widget/StoryRecyclerViewAdapter.java`, `MultiPageItemRecyclerViewAdapter.java`, `SinglePageItemRecyclerViewAdapter.java`, `SubmissionRecyclerViewAdapter.java`, `ThreadPreviewRecyclerViewAdapter.java`, `ItemRecyclerViewAdapter.java`, `ListRecyclerViewAdapter.java` | Added explicit attach(Context, RecyclerView) method with applicationComponent.inject(this) calls in adapters. Updated ItemManager qualifiers to use DataModule constants. Removed old Injectable runtime detection pattern from ItemRecyclerViewAdapter. | | **Data Clients**
